Introduction

The default retirement age and the associated statutory retirement procedure were repealed by the Employment Equality (Repeal of Retirement Age Provisions) Regulations 2011 which came into force on 6 April 2011.

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) wishes to encourage employees to work as long as they wish to do so, enabling it to retain necessary skills and experience of employees. The Trust does not have a compulsory organisational retirement age. This policy does not form part of any employee's contract of employment and may be amended from time to time.
MSE recognises that retirement can be a major life change and appreciate that stereotypes about older workers can still sometimes be an issue for staff and managers.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
To be a signpost for staff considering retirement in the short or medium term.
To act as signpost for managers to help them support employees.
To offer options for flexible retirement for employees to consider.
To facilitate the change from working to not working over a period of time to suit individual needs, whilst helping the MSE retain valuable skills and experience.
To encourage staff to consider their work-life balance when nearing the time they may wish to retire.
To encourage managers to be supportive of employees' needs.
This policy applies to all staff employed by the MSE.

Your retirement is when you choose to cease work on a flexible or permanent basis. The Trust considers that individuals should be supported to make decisions as to when and how to retire based upon their own circumstances and plans for the future.

Traditionally, other than as a result of illness or redundancy this decision has been closely linked with age. However, following the abolition of the default retirement age, the Trust no longer has a compulsory retirement age. However, age related criteria will apply in relation to pension benefits.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust

There will be a number of different people involved in the discussion and decision- making processes relating to an individual's retirement. The following gives the responsibilities of the relevant parties.
Employees
Employees should discuss their plans with their manager and employees will need to provide written confirmation of their wish to retire, in accordance with their contractual notice period.
Employees should attend pre-retirement courses as appropriate.

If you are a member of one of the NHS pensions schemes you should aim to give the pensions department at least four months' notice of your intention to retire to allow pension payments to be calculated and arranged as insufficient notice may result in a delay in the pension being paid.
Managers
Managers are responsible for:
Considering all requests for flexible retirement options fairly and provide written reasons for declining requests within two weeks of receiving a request.
Ensuring that this policy and procedure is implemented fairly and equitably with their service areas.
Ensuring that all employees are aware of this policy.
Acting promptly on receiving requests for retirement, including completion of termination form where relevant.

Following the correct process if the employee is planning to draw their pension but come back to work by completing a termination form and then direct the retiree through the recruitment process for potential re-hire. It is not sufficient to complete a change of conditions form as the employee will not be able to draw their pension.
Reminding the employee to contact the pensions department at least four months before retirement to obtain a retirement pack and to obtain their pension benefits from the NHS pension scheme.

Ensuring that employees are aware that they must take a break of at least two weeks before returning to employment. This is to break continuity of service for redundancy purposes. If the employee is retiring from the 1995 section of the NHS Pension Scheme, they will be subject to working a maximum ofhours per week during the first month of retirement.
Human Resources
The Human Resources Department will advise managers and staff when considering options and will act upon receipt of termination forms.
Ensure that all necessary retirement documentation is completed and passed to SBS.
Advise employee and managers on options for working post retirement. Occupational Health
Occupational Health will advise staff and managers on circumstances where ill health retirement may be appropriate.
NHS Pensions Department
The pensions department will:
Provide information to managers.
Provide information, quotes, and retirement packs to staff.
Pensions' information and administration is provided by NHS Shared Business Services (NHS SBS), on 0303 123 1144 or SBS-S.Pensions@nhs.net
Retirement options

Your retirement need not be a sudden move from ‘working' to ‘not working'. Applying for gradual or flexible retirement could be a useful way of preparing to cope with the difference between working regularly and full retirement. Potential flexible retirement options are open to all staff but need to be considered in relation to each individual's circumstances, job role and service need and the precise provisions of the pension scheme of which they are a member.
The right to return to employment with the Trust is not an automatic right, however the Trust values and appreciates the skills sets of staff and it is recognised that it
can be advantageous for both the employee and the service to be able to retain skilled and experienced staff.
You must discuss your options with your manager who will also need to take into consideration the needs and requirements of the service.
It is strongly recommended that you take advice and support during this time of consideration and planning. Details on where to find further help and information can be found in Appendix A.

Any potential Retire and Return to the Trust must follow a prescribed break. (This entails a full termination and re-hiring process through Trac and ESR systems in support of regulation pension requirements.)

There may be opportunities for employees to retire from the Trust and return to work within the same Directorate, either in their current role/an alternative vacant post and/or with reduced hours, after a designated break. However in order to ensure equitability of process; the correct termination of the pension assignment; and to ensure these preferences meet with the retirees needs, the needs of the business unit, ward or area, these staff will be required to apply for a new position as an external applicant alongside other potential suitable applicants for the role.

Staff re-joining the Trust will be required to obtain full NHS employers standard compliance checks which include, NHS application, referencing, Occupational Health clearance, Disclosure and Barring check, and submission of their right to work documentation.
Staff will be issued with a new Contract of Employment for their new role. (Substantive/Fixed Term)
The options most likely to be considered by the retiree and manager are below:
a) Retire completely.
b) Flexible retirement: (If available and possible to do so)
c) Reduce hours to graduate retirement (wind down).
d) Move to a post with a reduced level of responsibility (step down, if available).
e) Retire and apply to return to the same post on reduced hours (if suitable to do so)
f) Retire and apply to return to a different post (Via application process)
g) Retire and apply to return on an ad hoc basis (e.g., bank)

Each option discussed below is broadly described, but you should contact your pension provider or independent financial advisor to discuss your situation/options and the implications for your pension if you have one. The options and provisions may vary significantly between the three NHS pension schemes, the 1995, 2008 and 2015 schemes. If you are unsure which scheme, you are a member of, please contact NHS SBS to confirm. These are suggested options only and there is no guarantee that they are all suitable in your department. Please see Appendix A for some useful contact details and Appendix B for an application.
Wind down

As an alternative to simply retiring, you may be able to wind down by working fewer hours in your current post. You will need to discuss this option with your manager as the impact of your request on service delivery, patient care and will need to be considered. Please also refer to the Flexi-Working Policy which provides additional guidance for changes to working pattern. There is no guarantee that the request can or will be granted.

If you are a member of the NHS pension scheme, pensions for part-time staff are calculated on the whole-time equivalent days and salary, so if you wind down rather than retire, this will affect your eventual pension. In the meantime, you may be able to continue to build up pension entitlement. However, in view of pension reform, you need to check the most up-to-date position with the pensions department.
Step down

You may wish to reduce some of the pressures and responsibilities of work, and this may be achieved by stepping down into a less demanding job on lower pay but which still makes good use of your skills and experience, however this is also reliant on the service area being able to accommodate this request whilst meeting the operational need of the area. This option will be dependent upon a suitable post being available and you being successful in your application in any recruitment process. There is no guarantee that the request can or will be granted.
If you are claiming NHS Pension benefits there are restrictions on when you can return and in some cases, how much you can earn depending upon which scheme you are in.

The impact on your final pension will depend upon your age and which scheme you are in. If you are a member of the 1995 Section of the NHS pension scheme you may be able to apply for voluntary pay protection for the pension benefits you have accrued. However, you will need to check this with the pensions department.
In view of pension reform, you will need to check the most up to date position with your pension provider.
Retire and return
Taking your pension does not mean that you have to stop working. Returning to the same post or alternatively to a different post will be subject to usual Trust recruitment procedures.

There may be opportunities for employees to retire from the Trust and return to work within the same service area, either in their current role/an alternative vacant post and/or with reduced hours, after a designated break. However in order to ensure equitability of process and to ensure these preferences meet with the needs of the ward or service area and patient need, these staff will be required to apply for the post.
Following the termination of the retiree's current assignment they will be invited to apply for the post as an external applicant. This application will take place alongside
other potential applicants for the role. During the recruitment process the applicants would then need to discuss their potential flexible working requirements with the line manager.
Retire and return on an ad hoc basis

Employees may also choose to register for the Staff Bank by taking retirement, then opting to work on an ‘as and when' basis, giving them an opportunity to pick and choose their working hours, and working weeks. This however does not automatically guarantee that they will be working in the same role, department and or at the same grade as their retired substantive post.
The pressures within the NHS can vary depending on the time of year. Therefore, you may wish to retire and then come back during these peak periods on an ad hoc basis via the bank.
Coming back in all cases

In all cases, staff members will need to make sure that they have a two-week break in service. If staff are retiring from the 1995 section of the NHS Pension scheme after the  hours break they will be limited to working no more than 16 hours a week during the first month of retirement. A 24-hour break is required by the NHS Pension Scheme.
Returning to the same post or alternatively to a different post will be subject to usual Trust recruitment procedures.
Pension schemes

There are currently 3 pension schemes. All staff will be automatically enrolled into the NHS Pension scheme if eligible. They will not be eligible if they are full time in another trust paying into the NHS Pension scheme already. Those not eligible to join the NHS Pension Scheme are eligible to join NEST (National Employment Savings Trust) and will be automatically enrolled. They will be required to opt out if they do not wish this to continue a guide to the scheme will be sent to new starters. See Appendix A for contacts.
Not a member of the NHS pension scheme
Even if you are not a member of the pension scheme, MSE may be able to offer staff members a flexible work arrangement either before or after you retire, as above.
Formally agreeing and notifying retirement arrangements
You need to inform your manager in writing and must provide the pension department with at least four months' notice prior to retirement.

You should ensure that a termination form, and Application for Retirement Benefits (AW8) if applicable, is completed as soon as possible if you intend to retire completely or retire and come back. The AW8 form will be provided by the pension department once you notify them of your intention to retire.
In addition, if you would like to request one of the flexible retirement options outlined in section 5, you will need to complete the form provided in Appendix B and send this to your manager.
Retirement awards
Please refer to the MSE Recognition Policy for information on long service and retirement awards.
Training requirements
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.
